description.narrative: CTIC work programme implemented CTIC website operational

comment.narrative: Under the CTIC Business Plan 2012 – 2016 and the ICG Caribe/EWS workplan, capacity building and PAE activities have been conducted up to the end of 2013 largely funded through the ERC project. This has seen an expanded workplan and the Caribbean SIDS, particularly from the Eastern Caribbean more involved in the discussions of the CAIBE/EWS.

Community Hazards Identified through a Vulnerability and Capacity Assessment EWS installed and operational in community Sub-regional/regional tsunami trainings and activities conducted Re: New Enhanced Products to be issued by Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre Website developed

Bulk CTIC PAE materials and distributed to 8 Caribbean (Antigua and Barbuda, Bahamas, Barbados, Dominica, Grenada, Haiti, St. Kitts and Nevis, Trinidad and Tobago) countries Website is approximately 90% completed. The vast majority of the website content and graphics have been research, reviewed and referred to the website consultant Pacific Tsunami Warning Centre (PTWC) New Enhanced Products Training successfully convened during December 2015. The workshop was attended by 40 participants from the English, Dutch and French speaking Caribbean as well as Colombia ICG/CARIBE EWS Tsunami Ready Recognition Pilot Programme - St. Kitts and Nevis had completed the mapping phase, initiated the revision of the SOPs and sourcing of signage

Early Warning System developed in 1 community Community members further sensitized on hazards and necessary preparatory measures through - A minimum of 2 community meetings being convened - A minimum of 2 community activities around disaster mitigation and preparedness convened Development and dissemination of PAE/communications materials

Community members further sensitized on hazards and necessary preparatory measures through - community activities and events mainly revolving around schools - GPS mapping of vulnerable persons and documented in a report
Procurement and installation of radio interrupt EWS equipment in Saint Lucia and Barbados
Radio interrupt EWS equipment installed in Saint Lucia and Barbados within 3 radio stations

description.narrative: The development and implementation of the “Statistical Capacity Building Project to Support the Designing and Implementation of a Regional Strategy for the Development of Statistics to Support Evidence-Based Policy Making.”
Successful pilot of the extended LFS – MPI in Saint Lucia in preparation for national implementation and to support discussions at the OECS LSMC on the application of the sub-regional MPI

comment.narrative: Lack of multi-dimensional approaches to poverty measurement to inform evidence based decision making for policy and programme development
To develop and implement an RSDS Support formal adoption of MPI for national level implementation

Support evidence based policy formulation for social protection and poverty reduction through support for multi-dimensional approaches to poverty measurement, this in conjunction with the OECS Commission and OECS Member states; Enhance technical services in managing for development results through the provision of support for capacity building among technical persons at the Statistical Department

To develop and implement an RSDS Support formal adoption of MPI for national level implementation The purchae of tablet computers and other ICT equipment for the National Statistical Offices of Antigua & Barbuda, St Kitts and Nevis, and St Vincent

OECS LSMC RSDS validation workshop hosted in Barbados in April 2016, with other 25 representatives from the OECS countries, representation from the OECS, World Bank and ECCB. LOAs signed with Government of Grenada and Government of Saint Vincent for LFS-MPI survey implementation and capacity building continued.

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of end-to-end early warning systems for man-made crisis and all major natural hazards (e.g. geo-physical and climate-induced hazards)
Number of preparedness plans that cover only response
Number of preparedness plans that cover response AND recovery
Strengthening resilience and coping capacities in the Caribbean through integrated early warning systems
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

% of targeted beneficiary population know and are able to identify EWS alert messages and respond in an understandable and timely way Number of end-to-end CAP EWS functioning in communities and managed by national authorities, developed using a systematised regional framework Best practices, tools and experiences for implementing CAP-based EWS articulated and disseminated through regional online platform Comprehensive regional process articulated for implementing CAP EWS based on experiences Number of new EWS case studies developed and shared on active regional knowledge platform Number of countries in the region which recognise the integrated EWS model and commit to its adoption in the future

comment.narrative: Countries do not have preparedness systems in place to effectively address the consequences of and response to natural hazards Inadequate Number of end-to-end CAP EWS functioning in communities and managed by national authorities Communities are unable to identify EWS alert messages and respond in an understandable and timely way Lack of comprehensive regional process for implementing CAP EWS No current active regional knowledge platform

1. Community assessment of vulnerability and capacities undertaken - Support to capacity building in VCA methodology in 3 countries - Conduct VCAs and EWS assessment in at least 3 communities 2. KAP surveys conducted - KAP surveys completed in 7 communities 3. Participatory system design and validation - Community and national consultations - Analysis of gender and vulnerable groups needs 4. Installation, testing and training for alerting - Site and capacity assessment in 7 communities - System design 5. Improvement and integration of hazard monitoring systems - Site assessment in 7 communities - System design - Equipment procured for beneficiary communities
- User training

1. Supported Saint Lucia and Barbados country representatives to the DIPECHO regional meeting in the Dominican Republic during September 2015. These representatives were able to provide the country perspective on topics including the linkages between the Sendai Framework and the CDM Strategy; as well as Early Warning Systems. The CDEMA Alliance & Cooperation Services Manager from CDEMA were also funded through the project. 2. Through collaboration with the NDO, IFRC, FRC, local disaster committees, community volunteers, knowledge of risk and vulnerabilities was enhanced in two countries through capacity building of national actors in the Vulnerability Capacity Assessment (VCA) process as well as two VCAs being completed. The capacity building training on the VCA was completed in St. Vincent and the Grenadines and during October 2015 while VCA Training of Trainers was completed during November 2015 in Barbados. As part of these processes VCAs were completed in Vermont Valley (St. Vincent and the Grenadines) and Martins Bay (Barbados). On average 15 persons were trained. 3. Three (Vermont and South Rivers in St. Vincent and the Grenadines; Martins Bay Barbados) KAP surveys completed 4. Education Coordinators contracted in Dominica to lead on the public awareness and education activities in country 5. Hazard monitoring equipment (rain gauges and water level monitoring stations) procured for the 4 beneficiary countries 6. CAP servers (hardware) procured for Saint Lucia and Barbados through a Long Term Agreement (LTA) that the UNDP Barbados office has with Dell. 7. CAP specialist procured to assist with implementation o the technical elements of the project

1. Development of online platform on EWS 2. 7 country experiences captured through development of case studies 3. 1 regional workshop of EWS convened 4. VCA and EWS assessments completed in at least 2 communities 5. KAP surveys conducted in at least 2 communities 6. End to end EWS system functional in at least 2 countries

i. EWS toolkit information has been uploaded to the CDEMA website but some adjustments are still being made. Focus will continue to be on dissemination and informing partners of the toolkit development. Please view current toolkit at http://www.cdema.org/ under the CRIS section (left hand side of page). A more prominent infographic is currently being developed which will be placed on the website to link directly to the toolkit information. ii. EWS case studies are currently under development. Case study for Anguilla is finalised and awaiting upload to the toolkit. Draft case studies for Saint Lucia received and currently being reviewed. iii. Regional EWS meeting successfully convened after joint collaboration with IFRC, CADRIM, UNISDR, CDEMA and UNDP during 14 -16 April 2016. This workshop facilitated a 1) Shared understanding of the status of EWS in the Caribbean and requirements of key partners to successfully implement EWS in the Caribbean; 2) Increased awareness and capacity among regional and national partners for the successful implementation of EWS; 3) Awareness raised on the need for the consideration of vulnerable groups in the development and implementation of EWS and; 4) Deeper understanding of Partners/country representatives on the requirements needed to operate and maintain CAP Based EWS. 60 participants from the English, Spanish and French speaking Caribbean attended the workshop with the workshop also assisting with the development of the toolkit and case studies envisioned under the initiative. iv. Through collaboration with UNDP Cuba the initiative co-financed the Director of the Department of Instruments and Observation of the Meteorological Institute of Cuba to share the Cuba experience at the EWS regional meeting. v. The initiative supported the IFRC in contracting of a consultant to undertake a EWS desk review to consolidate the knowledge and experiences of EWS in the Caribbean. vi. The VCA for South Rivers and Vermont Valley (SVG) as wel

description.narrative: Preparation of an INDC for Barbados on long range planning for climate change-green economy, medium term development strategy and sustainable development aspiration.
The project shall focus on INDC preparation actions in accordance with established guidelines provided in the UNDP/World Resource Institute guidance document on Designing and Preparing an INDC.
Annual emissions of carbon dioxide (in metric tons) to be reduced or avoided described in INDC % of electricity to be generated from renewable energy sources described in INDC

comment.narrative: Greenhouse gas emissions: 1938 GgCO2e (2010) 710 connections from solar photovoltaic installations
60% of electricity from renewable energy sources by 2020 described in INDC

Barbados intends to achieve the following as articulated in the INDC submitted to the UNFCCC:
An economy-wide reduction in greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions of 44% compared to its business as usual (BAU) scenario by 2030. In absolute terms, this translates to a reduction of 23% compared with the baseline year, 2008. This equates to approx 1000 GgCO2e. As an interim target, the intention will be to achieve an economy-wide reduction of 37% compared to its business as usual (BAU) scenario by 2025, equivalent to an absolute reduction of 21% compared to 2008.
The above emission reduction contributions will be achieved through the mitigation actions in the energy and waste sectors, which accounted for the vast majority (88%) of GHG emissions in Barbados in 2008.
Renewable energy: contributing 65% of total peak electrical demand by 2030. Electrical energy efficiency: a 22% reduction in electricity consumption compared to a BAU scenario in 2029.
Development of national monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) system for tracking the implementation of the NDC
Multi-sector consultations underway; draft online MRV system developed and being populated.

title.narrative: Derisking the Transition from Fossil Fuels to Renewables

description.narrative: To accelerate the transition of Caribbean island economies from heavy dependence on fossil fuels to a diverse platform of renewables and energy efficiency and establish a blueprint for other SIDS
To accelerate the transition of Caribbean island economies from heavy dependence on fossil fuels to a diverse platform of renewables and energy efficiency and establish a blueprint for other SIDS

1. Number of countries signed on the Ten Island Challenge 2. CO2 emission reductions/year 3. % share of RE in the power generation mix of TIC countries 4. Number of RE/EE strategies and assessments with specific targets 5. Number of countries where implementation of comprehensive measures (plans, strategies, policies, programmes and budgets) to achieve low-emission and climate-resilient development objectives have improved (SP 1.4.2) 6. Number of islands applying the de-risking method, resource conservation measures and Ten Island Challenge tools 7. Number of Resource Conservation Measures (RCMs) modelled for health centres 8. Number of stakeholder partnerships active in Ten Island Challenge KM platforms disaggregated by sex, by age and by rural and urban 9. Number of local counterparts with improved capacity to partake in RE/EE developments disaggregated by sex, by age and by rural and urban 10. Installed RE capacity through Ten Island Challenge 11. Number of jobs and livelihoods/beneficiaries from Ten Island Challenge, disaggregated by sector and sub-sector, by sex, age, and excluded groups and by wage category were available and by rural and urban 12. Capital mobilised following support by Ten Island Challenge 13. Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women (SP1.5.1)

comment.narrative: High per capita CO2 emissions Few RE/EE strategies and assessments with specific targets High risks associated with investment in RE/EE technologies Limited employment opportunities in RE/EE fields Limited expertise in RE/EE technologies High capital costs and limited availability for RE investment

1.Carry out training and knowledge sharing workshop 2. Develop a knowledge infrastructure platform for RE technicians and policy-makers 3. Undertake RE/EE investments 4. Complete distribution and transmission grid assessments

1. Ministers of energy, utility executives and engineers, and regulators from across the Caribbean convened at an event organised to accelerate learning and share renewable energy best practices. Attendees at the Aruba Learning Event (ALE) expressed great enthusiasm for a Renewable Energy Community of Practice.
2. To ensure the online platform is successful, a partnership with the Caribbean Electric Utility Services Corporation was established. The project team collaborated with a consultant to design the structure and content requirements for the platform which is being hosted by CARILEC.
3. The project team developed and managed the procurement for (4) four Bahamas Government facilities energy retrofits and/or renewable energy generation. The project team will manage and oversee the contract and the process on behalf of the Government of Bahamas.
4. In partnership with the local utility, LUCELEC, in St Lucia, the project team completed a distribution and transmission grid integration study which will also inform the 3.2MW solar project on island. The results of this were shared at a data verification and analysis alignment workshop, planned to discuss all collected data and the forthcoming analyses and refine analytical approach based on feedback from the workshop.

1. Undertake analysis of national waste management planning and development of relevant management strategies 2. Complete distribution and transmission grid assessments 3. Launch the Online Platform 4. Investment in pilot RE/EE projects as a basis for up-scaling and replication

1. The project team worked to develop an Integrated National Waste Management Strategy for Grenada. One of the issues to be addressed is the need for future disposal capacity. An approach being considered is the construction of a new landfill and an assessment was undertaken to determine the feasibility of waste to energy technology for Grenada. This assessment will be fed into the national Energy policy.
2. The project team undertook a grid integration study for the purpose of assessing the integration of a potential geothermal energy project with the existing diesel and hydro generation on the main island of Saint Vincent in order to evaluate the impacts on the stability and reliability of the electricity grid.
3. The CARILEC platform was completed and launched in July of 2016 as the CARILEC Renewable Energy Community (CAREC).
4. The project team managed the tender process for 17MW system in the Bahamas as well as for equipment for two Belize Hospital energy retrofits. The team also prepared tender documents for a 3-MW Solar PV project near the international airport in Vieux Fort, St. Lucia.
